questions.question_text: What is the SNOWFLAKE.ACCOUNT_USAGE view that contains information about which objects were read by queries within the last 365 days (1 year)?

discussion.content: ACCESS_HISTORY

Selected Answer: C
C. ACCESS_HISTORY

The ANSWER is C. ACCESS_HISTORY.

The ACCESS_HISTORY view contains information about which objects were accessed (read, written, or updated) by queries within the last 365 days (1 year). This includes information about the user who performed the access, the time of the access, and the object that was accessed.

Selected Answer: C
ideally Two options are correct Access_History and LOGIN_HISTORY. As it has been asked to select any one so going with C
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/account-usage.html#account-usage-views

comments.content: Since asked ”which objects were read by queries ”, so the C must the only one answer.

discussion.content: C is correct answer, there are no views with name views_history and object_history

Selected Answer: C
Querying the ACCESS_HISTORY View

This Account Usage view can be used to query the access history of Snowflake objects (e.g. table, view, column) within the last 365 days (1 year).

questions.question_text: What are the three layers that make up Snowflake's architecture? (Choose three.)

choices.B: Yes, because the compute resource is replaced in its entirety with a new compute resource.
choices.C: No, because the size of the cache is independent from the warehouse size.
choices.D: Yes, because the new compute resource will no longer have access to the cache encryption key.
choices.A: Possibly, if the warehouse is resized to a smaller size and the cache no longer fits.

questions.question_text: Will data cached in a warehouse be lost when the warehouse is resized?

comments.content: Possibly, if the warehouse is resized to a smaller size and the cache no longer fits.

Based on this explanation, answer is B. 
YES, cached data is dropped.
right?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-considerations.html#scaling-up-vs-scaling-out. At the "tip" it states: ... which CAN impact performance ...
"Decreasing the size of a running warehouse removes compute resources from the warehouse. When the computer resources are removed, the cache associated with those resources is dropped, which can impact performance in the same way that suspending the warehouse can impact performance after it is resumed."
A Is correct answer
Correct Answer: A

B. Yes, because the compute resource is replaced in its entirety with a new compute resource.

When a Snowflake warehouse is resized, the current compute resources are replaced with new ones. This process clears the existing cache, and thus the cached data will be lost during the resizing operation.

Selected Answer: B
Decreasing the size of a running warehouse removes compute resources from the warehouse. When the computer resources are removed, the cache associated with those resources is dropped, which can impact performance in the same way that suspending the warehouse can impact performance after it is resumed.

Keep this in mind when choosing whether to decrease the size of a running warehouse or keep it at the current size. In other words, there is a trade-off with regards to saving credits versus maintaining the cache.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Answer is A
Decreasing the size of a running warehouse removes compute resources from the warehouse. When the computer resources are removed, the cache associated with those resources is dropped, which can impact performance in the same way that suspending the warehouse can impact performance after it is resumed.
